summary: This is a status update memorandum from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to the Federal Bureau of Prisons regarding the implementation of recommendations from the OIG's final report on the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's responses and the OIG's analysis of eight recommendations aimed at improving suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security camera policies.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the original OIG investigation and the subsequent recommendations to the BOP.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons submitted a status update to the OIG in response to the recommendations from the June 2023 final report.

events.title: BOP Incentives Reduction
events.description: The BOP reported that due to budgetary constraints, it is reducing or eliminating the use of staffing incentives effective this date.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death resulted in eight recommendations to the BOP; one (Recommendation 7) is closed, and the other seven remain 'Resolved' pending further BOP action.

The BOP is revising multiple Program Statements (5321.09, 5324.08, 5500.14, 4200.12) to address recommendations on cellmate assignment, suicide watch procedures, inmate monitoring, and security camera systems, but these revisions are subject to union negotiation.

The BOP reported improvements in staff retention rates (overall, Correctional Officers, Nurse Practitioners) due to incentives but stated it must reduce or eliminate those incentives starting March 23, 2025, due to budget constraints.

The BOP is seeking over $1 billion in funding from Congress over five years to cover special salary rates and to add 4,500 Correctional Officer and 200 nurse positions, based on a new Automated Staffing Tool.

The OIG will not close the recommendations until the BOP finalizes its policy revisions, provides the finalized policies for review, and provides further updates on staffing incentives, congressional reports, and salary proposals to OPM.
